_prev_prog_3.Description: Allen Family Foods, Inc. (Allen's) uses an Equipment Management System (EMS) to produce weekly, quarterly, semi-annual, and annual work orders as a means of maintaining their equipment.  Allen's also uses IIAR guidelines to perform an annual inspection of their equipment.  In addition to the general prevention program for the ammonia process, the following safety controls are provided for the following units:  Screw Compressor's have a low suction pressure alarm and cutout, high/low oil temperature alarm and cutout, high/low discharge pressure alarm and cutout, low oil pressure alarm and cutout, high level recirculation package alarm and cutout, and high/low discharge temperature alarm andcutout.  They also have a high motor current unload safety protection, high level cutout on Accumulators, and manual & automatic operation.  Water Chillers (WC1 - WC3), in addition to the general prevention program for the ammonia process, have a high liquid level solenoid cutout for a safety control.  In addition to the general prevention program for the ammonia process, Reciprocating Condensers (RC1 through RC6) have the following safety controls:  low suction cutout, high discharge cutout, low oil pressure cutout, high heat cutout, Vibration control, high motor current overload safety protection, and manual & automatic operation.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ALLEN HARIM FOODS, LLC



Allen Harim Foods, LLC (Allen Harim) operates and maintains a poultry-processing plant in Cordova, Maryland.  "Our mission is to create a safe work environment that encourages positive attitude by communicating honestly, directly and precisely with trust and respect for one another as we work and achieve a common goal which includes a quality product for our customers."  We empha safety in line operation, contractor selection and emergency response.  Our employees are trained to inspect, maintain and operate our equipment to prevent a release of hazardous material.  We have developed and implemented an Emergency Response Plan with a goal to minimize hazards to all employees, visitor and persons in the vicinity.



Poultry-processing requires significant refrigeration which is accomplished via the use of anhydrous ammonia at Allen Harim's Cordova Plant. 



This plant has a RMP Program 3 status for the operation of its ammonia refrigeration system used for cooling.  The Program 3 requires preparation of a worse case release scenario for the toxic material stored at this site.  The worst case would be the release of a 15,391.4-pound storage tank of ammonia.  The toxic endpoint would be 1.5 miles downwind.

 

The alternative case for an ammonia release is a 5-pound/minute (lb./min) release for 75 minutes which developed as a pinhole leak at a weld. between the shell and tube in the icemaker .  Personnel knowledgeable of the site-specific refrigeration equipment and the process developed this scenario.  RMP comp was used to calculate the end point based on the estimated time to discover the leak, to isolate the system and move the ammonia to another vessel. The estimated distance to toxic end point for this release is < 0.1 miles.  Operators are trained to use self-contained breathing apparatus to respond to ammonia release. 



Allen Harim has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program which is designed to prevent or minimize the c

onsequences of releases of ammonia at this site and complies with OSHA PSM regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  We maintain up to date piping and instrument drawings, Material Safety Data Sheets, and we have a written preventive maintenance program.  We use a computerized database program to produce work orders for regular preventative maintenance, yearly inspections and to maintain a history of the refrigeration equipment.  We use the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) inspection checklist for our yearly inspections.  If any problems are identified, corrective action will be documented on the work order.  Upon completion of the work order, entry into the database will provide a permanent record.  We have developed and updated our PSM manual with extensive employee participation.  We also use the database as a means to scheduled quarterly reviews with the PSM team to ensure that our PSM manual stays "a living document".  The PSM manual includes our operating procedures, which are updated as needed and reviewed each year.  Our operators are provided training relative to their respective duties.  They receive both on the job training and outside instruction, all training is documented.  A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study was conducted to identify and evaluate potential hazards.  The studies are updated every 5 years or when needed due to a change in the process.  Allens evaluates their PSM program by conducting compliance audits every three years using checklists developed by OSHA.  



During the last 5 years, there have been no reportable injuries associated with this process.



All Allen Harim employees receive hazard communications training during orientation, which includes evacuation procedures, emergency release notification and alarm signal recognition.  Allen Harim has also established an Emergency Response Team (Team) which is the first line of emergency response for the Cordova facility.  Employees designated as Emergency Response Personnel

are trained at the First Responder level to respond to a release of ammonia.  The makeup of the Team is diverse and includes refrigeration technicians trained in emergency shutdown procedures for the ammonia system. Allens maintain a close relationship with the local fire company.  The Plant will use 911 to notify appropriate outside agencies.  



Allen Harim has an active PSM program at the Cordova facility and meets regularly; therefore, Allen Harim should identify any needed saftey changes.
